intro: Lasiolytrum hispidum, commonly known as the hairy yellow-eyed grass, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green inflorescences that consist of numerous tiny flowers arranged in spikelets. Lasiolytrum hispidum is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and wetlands. Its hairy texture and unique flowering structure make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
